15.text:
A governess is a woman, probably young, but
not necessarily, could be middle aged, who

20.text:
lives with a family and is responsible for
the teaching of the girls, so that could be

26.text:
anywhere from about a five year old up to
an eighteen year old. She may also educate

32.text:
boys up until about the age eight, at which
point they go away to school. The governess

36.text:
could be teaching anything from very basic
stuff like the three R’s, reading, writing,

41.text:
arithmetic, right up to really quite complex
subjects, French, Italian, piano playing,

48.text:
use of the globes, which we know as geography
really, algebra.

54.text:
Governesses who taught older girls were responsible
for training them up in what were called accomplishments.

60.text:
Now these are the kinds of skills that girls
were assumed to need once they entered the

66.text:
middle class marriage market. So that might
include things like speaking French, playing

71.text:
the piano, deportment, you know, walking around
with a book on your head so that you have

77.text:
a straight spine, dance even, that kind of
basket of accomplishments and skills that

85.text:
make you ready to find a husband. But it wasn’t
just that that governesses taught. They were

90.text:
also responsible for their charges’ moral
education. They often superintended children’s

97.text:
prayers at night time, they heard them reading
from the Bible. They were constantly inculcating

103.text:
sort of normal moral truths about not lying,
not pinching your sibling, being grateful

110.text:
for everything, being kind to your parents.
So it was a difficult kind of job. I mean

115.text:
on the one hand, you’re teaching girls in
effect how to show off, on the hand, you’re

120.text:
also trying to teach them how to be good,
Christian women. It’s a very, very complicated

125.text:
role and it’s no wonder that an awful lot
of governesses found it an immense strain.

135.text:
The sort of person who was most likely to
become a governess was a young woman, from

139.text:
a middle class home, that is an educated home,
who for some reason just didn’t have a source

145.text:
of income. Her father perhaps had failed as
a businessman, or perhaps her brother has

152.text:
lost his job, perhaps her mother had died,
there was some reason why she didn’t have

158.text:
enough money and she needed to go out and
make some. And how she did that, without losing

164.text:
caste, without becoming shamefully working
class, was to go and live with another family,

170.text:
was to go and hire herself out as a sort of
surrogate mother in somebody else’s household.

180.text:
You’ve got a newly affluent middle class.
They want to ape the kind of ways of living

184.text:
of the aristocracy, and one way they can do
that is by hiring a more or less gentile woman

190.text:
to raise their daughters. So employing a governess
becomes a kind of mark of status, it’s kind

196.text:
of conspicuous consumption. It says, ‘Look,
I can afford to employ a woman, a gentile

202.text: young woman, to teach my children.’

210.text:
The governess occupied an incredibly awkward situation in the middle class home. I mean
she’s not one of the family but she’s

217.text:
not a servant either, and as result she found
herself really very, very much alone. The

223.text:
family was the family, they didn’t want
this extra person at the dinner table, it’s

228.text:
always awkward when you’ve got people whom
you don’t very well. In any case, she’s

232.text:
their employee, they can’t relax in front
of her. The servants meanwhile don’t want

236.text:
to be her friend, she’s stuck-up as far
they’re concerned. They have to serve her

241.text:
a separate meal, often in the schoolroom,
she makes extra work for them. That’s extra

247.text:
work, that’s more kind of journeys up the
stairs, that’s more washing up. Therefore

251.text:
really nobody likes her. And it’s a terribly
lonely situation.

255.text:
I think the phrase that really sums up the
governess is betwixt and between. She’s

260.text:
a woman who’s employed to look after somebody
else’s children, but she doesn’t have

264.text:
children herself. She’s a gentile lady,
but the family that employs her doesn’t

272.text:
really think that she’s smart enough to
sit down to dinner with them. And the servants,

277.text:
who wait on her, think really that she’s
no better than them and they really can’t

281.text:
stand her stuck up airs. She’s supposed
to dress appropriately, which means elegantly,

287.text:
but she doesn’t actually have enough money
really to get her boots repaired or to get

293.text:
her gloves cleaned. I mean, she’s in the
middle of a kind of lot of, lot of tensions,

298.text:
and living them out must have been an incredibly
uncomfortable situation in which to be.

307.text:
What’s absolutely extraordinary is how the
governess starts to pop up in novels of the

312.text:
period, from the 1840s and beyond. If you
think about Jane Eyre, she’s a governess.

316.text:
Becky Sharp of Vanity Fair, she’s also a
governess. I think the point is that novels

322.text:
in the 19th century needed a central figure,
a young person who’s going out to make their

327.text:
way in the world, and they need to have, you
know, no parents looking after them, no kind

332.text:
friends watching that they don’t go wrong.
They also need not to have any money of course,

337.text:
because they need to make their fortunes.
And the answer really is she’s going to

340.text:
have to be a governess. That is the only kind
of twenty-year-old girl who is going to have

347.text:
a story about going out into the world, who’s
going to be unprotected. Friendless is the

352.text:
word that the 19th-century uses. A friendless
girl who’s going to have adventures, who’s

358.text:
going to be absolutely respectable. We can’t
have a shop girl going out into the world,

362.text:
that won't make sense. We can’t have a prostitute
going out into the world, that really won't

367.text:
make sense to a middle class readership, so
we have to have the governess. She’s a fantastic
